The Tiantai Treatise on Ten Doubts says:
Reciting the Buddha's name at the time of death is the last thought.
That mind is fierce and sharp.
Reciting the Buddha's name once can lead to rebirth in the Pure Land.
This is because at the time of death, the mind is fierce and determined.
It is superior to the power of practicing for a hundred years.
Someone asked:
If one can be reborn by reciting the Buddha's name at the time of death,
why is it necessary to cultivate superior karma in advance?
The answer is:
It is uncertain whether a person will live a long or short life.
One may become seriously ill and confused,
or die suddenly at an untimely hour.
If one lacks goodness before death,
it will be difficult to escape the calamities of the next life.
One must create good causes in advance,
fearing to prevent such misfortune.
There are ten kinds of people who will not be able to recite the Buddha's name at the time of death:
First, one may not meet a good friend.
Second, one may be afflicted with illness and have a confused mind.
Third, one may have a stroke and be unable to speak the name.
Fourth, one may be delirious and lose one's mind, making it difficult to focus on the Buddha.
Fifth, encountering water or fire without the leisure for sincere intention.
Sixth, suddenly encountering tigers or wolves, frightened and in a hurry.
Seventh, at the last moment, bad friends destroy the mind of the Way.
Eighth, overeating too much, confused and lethargic to the point of death.
Ninth, in the army, fighting and suddenly dying.
Tenth, falling from a high cliff, injuring one's body and life.
Therefore, know that at the end of life, it is difficult to ensure good or bad.
One must cultivate in advance.
It can be said that when idle, do it in advance for use in an emergency.
Avoid having one's hands and feet in a flurry at the last moment.
